title: How to Remove Labels from Window Glass

steps.headline: Fill a 1-gallon (4 L) bucket with warm water.
Fill a second bucket with warm water and set it aside for rinsing.
Add 2 tablespoons (30 ml) of mild detergent to one of the buckets.
Swish the detergent around with your hand or a long-handled spoon until the water is sudsy.
Dip a sponge into the bucket, wring it out slightly, and apply it to the glass.
Use a glass scraper to remove the decal.
steps.description: Test the scraper first in an inconspicuous area of the glass to be sure it won’t leave a scratch.

steps.headline: If the sticker hasn’t completely come off, rub on a natural degreaser such as baby oil, cooking oil or mineral oil to remove any sticky residue left behind from the adhesive.
steps.description: Just dab a small amount of oil on a paper towel and rub it over the residue.

steps.headline: Dip a clean sponge into the rinsing bucket and wring out the excess water.
Dry the glass with a lint-free cloth or with crumpled newspaper.

text: Fill a 1-gallon (4 L) bucket with warm water.  Fill a second bucket with warm water and set it aside for rinsing.  Add 2 tablespoons (30 ml) of mild detergent to one of the buckets.  Swish the detergent around with your hand or a long-handled spoon until the water is sudsy.  Dip a sponge into the bucket, wring it out slightly, and apply it to the glass.  Use a glass scraper to remove the decal. Test the scraper first in an inconspicuous area of the glass to be sure it won’t leave a scratch. If the sticker hasn’t completely come off, rub on a natural degreaser such as baby oil, cooking oil or mineral oil to remove any sticky residue left behind from the adhesive. Just dab a small amount of oil on a paper towel and rub it over the residue. Dip a clean sponge into the rinsing bucket and wring out the excess water.  Wipe the glass clean.  Dry the glass with a lint-free cloth or with crumpled newspaper.
